_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Accidental Release Prevention Policies

The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System and Aqueous Ammonia Storage System.  The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The primary activity at the facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 21,800-gallon (gal) storage tank (bullet tank) at the site.   The Wilbur-Ellis, Dixon facility also stored up to 30 1,000-gallon nurse tanks that could contain anhydrous ammonia at any given time.  The facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity to 82 percent (%) of the fill capacity for both covered processes.  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 162,020 pounds (lb.). Aqua ammonia (24% of quantity by weight) is stored in two 25,000-gallon above-ground storage tanks at the site. The maximum quantity of ammonia handled is 45,240 pounds (lb.).

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Worst-Case/Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary

Per CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario have been defined for each process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Risk Considerations

Ammonia is a toxic inhalation hazard; and thus, the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks to potentially reach sensitive populations within the commun

ity. The facility's identified potential risks for an ammonia release from its process are included in the off-site consequence analysis, Hazard Assessment, and Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). Facility RMP elements and other safety programs are structured to minimize the potential of a release from the identified risks.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 2 and Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia.  Prevention elements for each program are listed in Table 1 below.

 

List of Prevention Program Elements 

Aqueous Ammonia Storage Prevention Program 2 Elements

   ? Safety Information

   ? Hazard Review

   ? Operating Procedures

   ? Training

   ? Maintenance

   ? Compliance Audits

   ? Incident Investigation

Anhydrous Ammonia Storage Prevention Program 3 Elements

   ? Process Safety Information

   ? Process Hazard Analysis

   ? Operating Procedures

   ? Training

   ? Mechanical Integrity

   ? Management of Change

   ? Pre-Startup Safety Review

   ? Compliance Audits

   ? Incident Investigation

   ? Employee Participation

   ? Hot Work Permit

   ? Contractors



Five-Year Accident History

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqueous at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  



External Events Analysis

Pursuant to the requirements of CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, ?2745.7(q), general events external to the plant are addressed in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the anhydrous ammonia process.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions:

   1)    The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA ?2760.2 or Hazard Review (HR) ?2755.2.  During the PHA, a broad list of external events was considered by the Study Team.  The external events that were consid

ered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact.

   2)    The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered.  If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the Administering Agency (AA) to determine what is required.  If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.

The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.

   3)    For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 

     ?    The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

     ?    Major hazards identified;

     ?    Process controls in use;

     ?    Mitigation systems in use;

     ?    Monitoring and detection systems in The Facility's 2009 PHA are in the process of being reviewed and updated. Section 8.a. of this RMP will be corrected when the PHA review and updates are completed (targeted completion by 11/1/2014); and,

     ?    Changes since the last HR or PHA



Emergency Response Program

Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  The Wilbur-Ellis Dixon Facility will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders.  The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.  An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220 is in place.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Wilbur-Ellis is committed to continuously making safety improvements. To improve the safety of the anhydrous ammonia system, Wilbur-Ellis is in the process of developing a more comprehensive anhydrous ammonia inspection checklist for the bullet tank system and nurs

e tanks. The comprehensive checklist will include daily, weekly, and annual inspection frequencies, including visual and non-destructive tests to evaluate the mechanical integrity of the tanks, valves, piping, etc. At a minimum, inspection frequencies will follow industry standards.

Wilbur-Ellis is also implementing a facility-wide comprehensive corrective action/preventative action (CAPA) log to track and facilitate completion of listed CAs on a timely basis. Recommended improvements and identified deficiencies from the inspection checklists, compliance audits, and PHA studies will be included on the facility CAPA log along with the priority, employee responsible, and targeted completion dates.
